repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Primary School Teacher
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, with
            a likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impact. Nonetheless, lessons address issues
            regarding targeted recruitment, and quality improvement. The
            innovative recruitment scheme, was targeted to voluntary
            candidates entering the D2 (five-semester post Secondary
            Diploma Course) program, also offered to teachers from
            deprived, and remote areas, granting the opportunity to
            upgrade their skills, and access preferential treatment to
            the civil service, through a teaching post upon graduation,
            additionally enhanced by the possibility of returning to the
            rural areas. This became an equity objective, since not only
            were teachers more committed to their own communities, but
            they had the advantages of knowing the local language, and
            the acceptance of belonging to the community. However, this
            scheme proved mostly short lived, based on the recruitment
            dilemma for the highest scoring, a selection not necessarily
            from deprived areas, but on average from urban areas.
            Furthermore, education quality improvement will not be
            sustained, unless action plans maximize staff utilization,
            and support a continued development, in a collaborative
            effort by institutions, participants, and external
            contributors, with the need to model the program along a
            wide range of pedagogic approaches, redefining the role of
            head teachers in accordance to the country's changing context.

Conformed Copy - L3496 - Primary School

display_title.display_title:
Conformed Copy - L3496 - Primary
            School Teacher Development Project - Loan Agreement

5079271.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Primary School Teacher
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will enhance the training of
            primary school teachers through a new tertiary level teacher
            diploma course.  This will be achieved by provision of
            relevant civil works, equipment, books and learning
            materials, technical assistance, staff development, and
            operational support for:  (a) developing primary teacher
            educators; (b) strengthening primary teacher education
            programs; (c) establishing a coordinated system for teacher
            supply and distribution; (d) building capacity for research
            and development (R&D) in primary education; and (e)
            strengthening the management of the primary teacher
            education system.  Component (a) will provide support for a
            variety of in-country and overseas training programs for
            teacher educators and for generating local capacity to
            conduct master's level programs for primary teacher
            educators and researchers.  Component (b) will improve the
            diploma program and curricula materials.  Under component
            (c) a coordinated system for teacher supply and distribution
            will be established by setting up a tracking system to
            facilitate decision-making concerning trainees and
            recruitment efforts.  Component (d) will provide for the
            development of R&D capacity among primary teacher
            educators for research directed towards the improvement of
            the effectiveness of primary teacher education and related
            issues.  Component (e) will support initiatives for
            establishing a Subdirector for Teacher Education.
